script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Welcome to the Come Follow Me Podcast by Gospel Study App. I'm Sarah.

script.speaker: David
script.text: And I'm David. Happy to be here!

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: David, I have to start with a mystery that’s been nagging at me as I studied this week’s readings in Genesis 3-4 and Moses 4-5. Why did Adam and Eve, after being cast out of the Garden of Eden, express joy about their Fall? It seems like such a paradox—leaving paradise for a world of pain and sorrow, yet they’re glad. What are we missing here?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, that’s a brilliant question, and it cuts right to the heart of the restored perspective we get from the Book of Moses. Most people see the Fall as a tragedy, but there’s a profound truth hidden in plain sight. In Moses 5:11, Eve says, ‘Were it not for our transgression we never should have had seed, and never should have known good and evil, and the joy of our redemption, and the eternal life which God giveth unto all the obedient.’ Let’s unpack that—there’s a pattern here that shifts everything.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wait, so you’re saying the Fall wasn’t just a loss, but a doorway to something greater? I’m intrigued, but I need to understand how they could feel joy amidst the consequences. Let’s set this up from multiple angles—how did ancient Israel view the Fall, how does Christ’s perspective change it, and what do we learn from modern revelation?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly, Sarah. Let’s start with ancient Israel’s view, as reflected in Genesis 3. To them, the Fall was often seen as the origin of sin and suffering—God curses the serpent, Eve is told she’ll bear children in sorrow, and Adam must toil for his bread by the sweat of his brow. It’s a story of separation from God, a divine punishment. But that’s only the first layer.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Okay, that makes sense for the Old Testament lens. But how does Christ’s coming reframe this narrative? I feel like there’s a pivot here that changes the tone.

script.speaker: David
script.text: It absolutely does. Through Christ’s Atonement, the Fall becomes the setup for redemption. In Moses 5:10-11, Adam and Eve learn from an angel about the Savior’s role. Adam says, ‘Blessed be the name of God, for because of my transgression my eyes are opened, and in this life I shall have joy.’ Christ turns the Fall into the first step toward eternal life, not the end of the story.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s fascinating. And modern revelation seems to add even more depth, right? How does the restored gospel complete this picture?

script.speaker: David
script.text: It does, Sarah. In 2 Nephi 2:25, Lehi teaches, ‘Adam fell that men might be; and men are, that they might have joy.’ Modern prophets clarify that the Fall was a necessary part of God’s plan, not a mistake. It’s about agency, opposition, and growth—elements we couldn’t have experienced in Eden’s static perfection.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love how those perspectives converge. So let’s trace this pattern of the Fall as a necessary step across dispensations. Where do we see this idea of growth through opposition showing up again?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let’s look at Moses first. In Moses 4:1-4, we see the premortal council where agency is central—Satan’s plan to destroy choice is rejected. This sets up the need for opposition, which Lehi later explains in 2 Nephi 2:11: ‘For it must needs be, that there is an opposition in all things.’ Without the Fall, there’s no opposition, no growth.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: So opposition starts in the premortal realm and carries into mortality. Where else do we see this pattern of falling to rise?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Notice this in Christ’s ministry. His descent—His suffering and death—is the ultimate Fall that enables our rise through the Resurrection. It echoes Adam’s Fall but on a cosmic scale. And in Doctrine and Covenants 29:39, we learn that opposition allows us to choose, to be tested, and to become like God.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s powerful. So this pattern repeats—Adam and Eve, Christ, and even us in our personal journeys. I’m seeing a thread of divine purpose in falling and rising. But let’s dig into some historical context. What do we know about how ancient cultures understood this story?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Great question. In ancient Near Eastern cultures, creation and fall narratives often focused on chaos and order, with humanity caught in divine conflict. But what’s unique about the Genesis account is the personal relationship with God—Adam and Eve aren’t just pawns; they’re given agency. Archaeological finds, like ancient Mesopotamian texts, show similar garden motifs, but none emphasize choice and redemption like the biblical account does.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a time-collapse moment for me—seeing how the restored gospel adds layers to these ancient stories. What’s another cultural insight that might surprise us?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s where it gets interesting. The concept of clothing in Moses 4:27, where God clothes Adam and Eve, has deep cultural significance. In ancient temple traditions, being clothed by deity symbolized covenant protection and priesthood authority. This isn’t just about covering nakedness—it’s a foreshadowing of temple covenants we participate in today.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: Wow, I never saw that connection. So let’s circle back to our opening mystery—why were Adam and Eve glad? How does this all tie together?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s the resolution, Sarah. Adam and Eve were glad because the Fall opened the door to experience, to family, to knowing good and evil, and ultimately to redemption through Christ. As Eve says in Moses 5:11, they saw ‘the joy of our redemption.’ Their Fall was the first step in God’s plan for their exaltation—and ours.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s remarkable. It’s not a tragedy; it’s a triumph in disguise. I’m starting to see hidden connections everywhere now. For instance, how does this link to other scriptures we might not immediately think of?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Let’s connect this to 2 Nephi 9:14, where Jacob teaches that at the resurrection, ‘we shall have a perfect knowledge of all our guilt, and our uncleanness, and our nakedness; and the righteous shall have a perfect knowledge of their enjoyment.’ The Fall introduced nakedness—both literal and spiritual—but Christ’s Atonement clothes us in righteousness.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a beautiful cross-reference. What about linking this to the temple, as you hinted earlier?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly. In Doctrine and Covenants 109:22-26, the Kirtland Temple dedication prayer speaks of being clothed with power from on high. Just as God clothed Adam and Eve, temple covenants clothe us spiritually, protecting us and preparing us for eternal life. It’s a direct echo of the Garden story.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I’m blown away by how interconnected this is. What’s another surprising link across the standard works?

script.speaker: David
script.text: Here’s one most people miss. In Revelation 7:9, 13-15, John sees a multitude clothed in white robes, washed in the blood of the Lamb. This imagery ties back to Moses 4:27—God’s clothing of Adam and Eve prefigures the ultimate cleansing through Christ. It’s a thread from Eden to the Second Coming.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That gives me chills. These connections show such divine consistency. Now, how do we apply this ancient pattern to our modern lives? I want to bring this home for our listeners.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Sarah, it’s all about seeing our own falls—our struggles and mistakes—as part of God’s plan for growth. Just as Adam and Eve found joy in redemption, we can find purpose in our challenges by turning to Christ. President Nelson has taught that the Atonement is for daily use, not just big sins. We rise through Him every day.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s so practical. So our personal falls, when met with repentance, mirror Adam and Eve’s journey. It’s not about avoiding struggle; it’s about learning through it. David, this perspective changes how I see my own life.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Exactly. And as teachers or parents, we can help others see this too. Encourage them to study Moses 5:10-11 and ask, ‘How can my challenges lead to joy?’ It’s a powerful discussion starter for family night or a class.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: I love that actionable idea. Before we wrap up, David, what’s one final thought or invitation you’d like to leave with our listeners based on what we’ve discovered today?

script.speaker: David
script.text: I’d invite everyone to reread Moses 5:11 this week and ponder Eve’s words about the joy of redemption. Ask yourself, ‘How can I see God’s hand in my own falls and rises?’ Let this story remind you that every step, even the hard ones, is part of His plan for your eternal joy.

script.speaker: Sarah
script.text: That’s a beautiful invitation, David. Thank you for joining me today to uncover these profound truths. I know I’m walking away with a renewed perspective on the Fall, and I hope our listeners are too.

script.speaker: David
script.text: Thanks, Sarah. It’s always a privilege to explore these layers of scripture with you. I’m excited for what we’ll discover next time!
